description: Twirled Readout Error eXtinction (TREX) is a model-free readout error mitigation technique that avoids the exponential cost of full confusion-matrix inversion. Instead of characterizing the full \(2^n \times 2^n\) assignment matrix, TREX uses randomized bit flips before measurement to diagonalize the readout noise channel.
TREX is implemented as resilience level 1 in IBM's Qiskit Runtime. It is particularly attractive because it requires no prior characterization of the readout noise and adds minimal overhead.

The key insight is that applying a uniformly random Pauli-X bit flip to each qubit before measurement, and tracking the flip classically, transforms an arbitrary readout-error channel into a diagonal (multiplicative) channel. Each Pauli observable then picks up a single multiplicative bias factor that can be estimated and divided out.
how_it_works: For each shot, independently and uniformly at random, decide whether to apply a Pauli-X gate to each qubit immediately before measurement.
Record the random bit-flip pattern alongside the measurement outcome.
In classical post-processing, undo the known bit flips to recover the intended measurement result.
The random twirling diagonalizes the readout-error transfer matrix: each Pauli observable \(P\) acquires a multiplicative factor \(\lambda_P\).
Estimate \(\lambda_P\) from calibration circuits (e.g., preparing \(|0\rangle^{\otimes n}\)) and divide the raw expectation value by \(\lambda_P\) to obtain the corrected result.
advantages: Model-free: no need to characterize the full readout-error matrix
Avoids exponential cost of \(2^n \times 2^n\) matrix inversion
Simple to implement — only requires random X gates before measurement
Scales well to large qubit counts
Composable with gate-noise mitigation techniques (ZNE, PEC, etc.)
disadvantages: Only addresses readout errors, not gate errors
Correction accuracy depends on stability of readout-error rates between calibration and experiment
Division by small \(\lambda_P\) amplifies statistical noise for high-weight Pauli observables
use_cases: Default readout-error mitigation in IBM Qiskit Runtime (resilience level 1)
Preprocessing step before gate-error mitigation (ZNE, PEC)
Large-scale experiments where full confusion-matrix calibration is infeasible
Any expectation-value estimation on noisy hardware
